body_html: You could try switching your code to use tf.data for the input pipeline and tf.train.MonitoredSession for the session. These classes create far fewer threads than the Slim-based training code, and should be able to fit in the limit of 28 threads if you also limit the inter_op_parallelism_threads and intra_op_parallelism_threads.
body_text: You could try switching your code to use tf.data for the input pipeline and tf.train.MonitoredSession for the session. These classes create far fewer threads than the Slim-based training code, and should be able to fit in the limit of 28 threads if you also limit the inter_op_parallelism_threads and intra_op_parallelism_threads.
body: You could try switching your code to use `tf.data` for the input pipeline and `tf.train.MonitoredSession` for the session. These classes create far fewer threads than the Slim-based training code, and should be able to fit in the limit of 28 threads if you also limit the `inter_op_parallelism_threads` and `intra_op_parallelism_threads`.
